awd_titl_txt: CSR: NeTS: Medium: Achieving High-Availability in the Face of Rapid Network Evolution in Large Content Providers
awd_abstract_narration:
Global Internet services, such as web search, social networking, video dissemination, and cloud computing are built on data centers that are large warehouses full of computers. The computers in the data centers are connected together, and to the Internet, by a network. If that network goes down then the computers it connects and the Internet services they support also go down. This project aims to decrease, by one to two orders of magnitude, how long those networks are down each month.

The project will explore the design of two components that can contribute significantly towards decreasing network downtime.  One component will be a new highly-available control plane that will include a new replication protocol that provides strong consistency and resilience to the failure of an external failure detector while retaining as many of the desirable properties of current less-available designs (e.g., small resource footprint) as possible. The other component will be an automated management plane that will raise the level of abstraction of specifying a management operation (MOp) on the network, thereby allowing automated software to  synthesize and manage the sequence of steps necessary to achieve a complex network MOp such as upgrading software on a large network.

Global Internet services are an integral part of modern life and increasing their availability will benefit society. The project plans include developing software prototypes and working closely with large Internet services to increase the likelihood of technology transfer.  The research in the project will be conducted by graduate students and undergraduate students that will learn how networks work, how to build and improve them, and how to build and improve the computer systems that control them.  Each of these skills is likely to be increasingly important in the coming years.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
The Internet is a crucial tool for economic and social development, and the availability of the network defines Internet user experience today. The major goal of the project was to explore the principles, and associated methods, that can contribute significantly towards attaining five 9s network availability by improving two major components of networks: the management plane that ensures networks can be upgraded, react to component failures, etc. and the replicated state machines (RSMs) that provide fault-tolerant execution of network management actions.

The main outcomes of the project are:

Slowdown tolerance RSMs: Ensuring extremely high availability requires that RSMs be able to execute even if one of their constituent machines. We developed a definition of slowdown tolerance and found that nearly all existing protocols were not slowdown tolerant, while the few had poor performance. We then designed, implemented, and evaluated several new slowdown tolerance RSM protocols. These protocols provide bounded slowdown tolerance with latency (i.e., time to complete an action) that is comparable to the non-slowdown-tolerant protocols used in practice today.

Lifecycle Management Complexity of Datacenters: With datacenters living on for years, sometimes up to a decade, their lifecycle costs can be high. A data center design that is hard to deploy can stall the rollout of services for months; this can be expensive considering the rate at which network demands have historically increased. A design that is hard to expand can leave the network functioning with degraded capacity impacting the large array of services that depend on it. To understand management complexity, we have designed complexity metrics that can be indicative of lifecycle management costs (e.g., capital expenditure, time and manpower required). These can be used to evaluate and compare network designs.

Routing Designs for Structured Networks: For topology designs with low management complexity that deviate from folded-Clos, the design of scalable routing algorithms that can achieve their designed capacity was an open question. We have designed oblivious routing techniques for FatClique and DRing. We show that we can use the topological structure and graph automorphism to reduce the problem size to a point that is tractable for an off-the-shelf solver running on commodity hardware. To do this, we first prove the existence of an optimal solution that is invariant to automorphism--the solution is a permutation of itself. Based on this result, we reduce the search space of an optimal solution to the solution that is automorphism-invariant. Using graph automorphism, we formulate a robust multi-commodity flow problem with significantly fewer variables and constraints to derive near-optimal routing.
